page.title: 08WET-LANDS OF THE RIVER ARUN
page.content: The eastern edge of Arundel Park forms a sheer drop to a narrow road below. A dis-used chalk quarry is detectable towards the end of this deciduous tree-clad hanger. This open road from Arundel runs beside the Wildfowl Trust and its accompanying car-parks. Uncultivated wet-land, drained by dykes border the road leading to the Black Rabbit Inn on the banks of the river Arun. This river flows past Offham, upstream to South Stoke and beyond. Wet-land borders either side of the river. Drained by dykes, it affords grassland and grazing for cattle. As the ground rises toward Arundel Park arable and pasture land intermingle. A few houses cluster near the pub, Offham has a dozen or so, two nestle down near the Arun. Crops and cattle rather than people.
